## Oyster predictions

The `Oysters` dataset in the `Stat2Data` package contains the results of an experiment comparing two different methods for measuring oyster size. You can load the data in R as follows:

```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(Stat2Data)
data(Oysters)
```

The engineers who conducted the study want to know if a new 3-D measuring system (`ThreeD`) is better at predicting oyster volume than the old 2-D (`TwoD`) measuring system.

:::{.question}
#### Question 5

Create two scatterplots, one showing the relationship between the 3-D measurements and oyster volume, and the other showing the relationship between the 2-D measurements and oyster volume.
:::


### Correlation, SSE, and RMSE

To quantify the strength of the linear relationship between two quantitative variables, we can calculate the correlation coefficient. 

:::{.question}
#### Question 6

Calculate correlation coefficients for the two scatterplots you created in the previous question. The [course codebook](https://sta112-s26.github.io/resources/codebook.html) includes examples of calculating correlation if you get stuck!
:::

In class we also talked about SSE and RMSE as related ways to summarize the predictive performance of a model. But first we need to fit a model! The code below will fit a linear model in R and calculate the SSE and RMSE:

```{r}
model_2d <- lm(Volume ~ TwoD, data = Oysters)
sum(model_2d$residuals^2) # SSE
sqrt(mean(model_2d$residuals^2)) # RMSE
```
